events.name: Tech Jam 2016 -Hour of Code
events.description:
Introducing visitors to code, prototype and build things, to fail fast and learn quickly. Tech Jam 2016, presenting Hour of Code SG aims to teach children how to begin coding in an easy and interactive manner.
The Hour of Code  was launched in the US in 2013 as an online campaign to introduce coding to the public in a friendly and interactive manner. The Hour of code campaign introduces kids aged 5 and up into programming. This week long coding and programming festival includes showcases, hands on activities and workshops. Activities are free, pre registration is required. Admission to Science Centre applies to non members.
events.location: Science Centre Singapore, 15 Science Centre Road 609081

events.name: Ruby Tea Party December 5
events.description:
Your chance to sit down and dedicate yourself to learning programming. 


Our goal is to make the Ruby on Rails community in Singapore more inclusive for women and other minorities - so if you know anyone that codes or that you think would enjoy learning to code, invite them along!Â  


If this is your first time, don't worry! We will help you get set up and going in no time.Â  

If you are eager, have a look at www.tryruby.org (Do the first 3 or 4 levels - stop when you get to Files and Directories!)Â  

And then get started onÂ  http://guides.railsgirls.com/app/. 

See you Monday!Â

events.name: DataJam!
events.description: We're looking to increase our contributions to the social sector here in Singapore, and will be having a monthly meeting for volunteers who want to do more. These will be working sessions which can include:Â  â€¢Â DataJams where data is cleaned and prepped for further analysis,Â  â€¢Â Clinics for social sector organisations to drop in and ask data-related questions, and â€¢ Planning sessions for wider community events.Â  This is a closed, by-invitation only session for volunteers whom we've worked with before. If we've forgotten you (sorry!) or you're new and have a burning desire to join these sessions, please send us a message! For others who can't make it regularly, these sessions are helping us have more community-wide events. Please understand that no food will be provided, so do make preparations to grab a bite before you turn up. More details to come! Agenda 6.45 - 7pm: Registration7 - 7.30pm: Data review and task assignment7.30 - 9.30pm: Data cleaning
events.location: #03-04, IDA labs @ National Design Centre,  #03-04, 111 Middle Road, 188969, Singapore

events.name: Papers We Love #023
events.description:
Paper #1: Kqueue: A generic and scalable event notification facility - Jonathan Lemon : Javier AlcÃ¡zarz

Paper #2: ??
-------------------

What was the last paper within the realm of computing/technology you read and loved?

What did it inspire you to build or tinker with? 

Come share the ideas in an awesome academic/research paper with fellow engineers, programmers, and paper-readers. 

Lead a session and show off code that you wrote that implements these ideas or just give us the lowdown about the paper (because of HARD MATH!). Otherwise, just come, listen, and discuss.

-----------------

Original Meetup : http://www.meetup.com/papers-we-love
Papers Repo : https://github.com/papers-we-love/papers-we-love

events.location: HackerspaceSG, 344B King George's Avenue, King George's Building, Singapore 208576

events.name: Ransomware in Web Apps
events.description: In recent years, ransomware has become a major problem for individuals and enterprises alike. A large attack surface, low barriers to entry and good rewards make it a very attractive option for attackers. We are already seeing hackers try out new infection vectors like social media (http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/locky-ransomware-self-downloading-image-files/) and targets like IoT and PoS systems (http://www.theverge.com/2016/11/27/13758412/hackers-san-francisco-light-rail-system-ransomware-cybersecurity-muni). In this talk, we will demonstrate and show PoC exploits on how ransomware can move up the stack from desktop apps to enterprise apps using a novel attack vector of library dependencies and package managers. Protecting and securing your software supply toolchain is going to be of paramount importance against such threats. Speaker: Mark CurpheyMark Curphey is CEO of SourceClear, the security company for software developers. He founded OWASP (http://www.owasp.org) when he ran software security at Charles Schwab and has written chapters on software security in books published by Oâ€™Reilly.
events.location: Akamai Singapore office, 1 Raffles Place, #16-61, One Raffles Place Tower 2, Singapore 048616
